content.webTitle: England’s Mike Brown admits he was tempted to lie over concussion

fields.headline: England’s Mike Brown admits he was tempted to lie over concussion
fields.bodyText: About the only thing Mike Brown can hazily remember is being rolled on to the spinal board. Otherwise there is still a big missing chunk in his recollection of his last game for England, sandwiched between knowing he was struggling to catch an Italian high ball and waking up in the medical room with a sore head. It is the rest of us who can recall every detail of one of Twickenham’s nastier modern collisions. Brown being Brown, what hurt most was having to miss the subsequent Ireland game while he went through the painstaking return-to-play protocols that all concussion victims must now complete. Before sense prevailed, he admits he was tempted to lie about feeling better in a desperate effort to retain his place in Dublin. “If I wasn’t so aware of the implications and the dangers ... yeah, I probably would have,” he says. “Pulling out is one of the worst things I’ve ever had to go through in my whole life. As a sportsman everything you work towards is pulling on your country’s jersey. If it wasn’t for the awareness courses we’ve been on, I probably wouldn’t have done so. I wouldn’t have done myself justice, would have put myself in danger and it wouldn’t have been good.” He says it so matter-of-factly it is possible to underestimate his honesty, at a time when the issue of concussion management has never been bigger. Anyone seeking a glimpse into the mindset of an international player may just have found the most fascinating case study of the lot. While Brown, at 14st 7lb, is not the biggest of players, his commitment is other-worldly. The days of mad, crazy‑fool bravado are supposedly over, but strength of character can still take you places the sane never go. Which at least partially explains why, at 7.30am on the Friday morning after the Italy game, Brown sat on his bed seriously contemplating keeping quiet about the headaches he had experienced during the night. “I’ve trained through headaches before – not from concussion but through being dehydrated – so I could definitely have trained on and seen how it went,” he says. In that event he could have played against Ireland but, ultimately, the fear of letting down his team-mates outweighed all else. “It wouldn’t have been good preparation for the team if I’d pulled out late. We speak about being truthful, telling the medical team how you’re feeling and the risks that go with not letting people know. That was enough for me to pull out.” Unsurprisingly, he has yet to watch the Italy match but one or two kind people have sent him clips of the incident. “I’ve seen a couple of pictures of the hit, which was nice: great facials and then asleep on the floor,” he says. “But it happens in rugby. It’s a collision sport. I remember having my eye on the ball and at the last minute realising I couldn’t get there to catch or compete for it myself. Then I went for the tackle and that’s it. I only came round fully in the medical room. One of the first things I said when I could speak was: ‘Let my fiancee know.’ I was quite proud of myself.” As it turned out England’s backroom staff had already reassured Eliza, the daughter of the former England footballer Tony Woodcock, that he was fine. She was able to ring family members and tell them that long before the battered full-back reappeared on the bench to a huge ovation. It is one of the occupational hazards, from Eliza’s point of view, of having a partner who fears very little other than losing. This is a man who, after being inadvertently locked in her flat one morning, jumped out of a first-floor window to get to training. Watching the Ireland game almost drove him to distraction. “Eliza was trying to calm me down but I wasn’t having it,” he says. “I was fuming. I wasn’t happy at all. It wasn’t something I want to be doing too regularly, sat in my lounge on the edge of my sofa, screaming at the TV. I had to have a quiet moment to myself at half-time. It wasn’t a good day. Unfortunately, my fiancee had to go through it with me.” No wonder Stuart Lancaster, when asked this week to single out the 29-year-old’s best quality, plumped for his “winner’s mentality” above everything else. “When it comes down to the fine margins on selection – technically, tactically, physically – the intangible is that and he has it,” Lancaster said. “Even though he is not that vocal off the field, his sheer competitiveness is what you want in your team.” Brown is not entirely convinced – “I think Stuart just means I get grumpy if I don’t get my own way” – but ask him if he thinks Celtic players are more passionate than the English and his eyes glitter. “Definitely not. I love playing for my country. It’s everything I’ve worked towards and it means so much it’s hard to put into words. I try and bring that into every performance when I’m lucky enough to wear the jersey.” That shows during the anthems, never mind the game. It has been a long road to Twickenham from his early comprehensive school days in Salisbury. His parents split up when he was 12 and his father, Mick, formerly with the fire service, now struggles to get to matches because of his multiple sclerosis. There is plenty to think about in those emotional moments before kick-off. “My fiancee is usually sat in the family section right opposite me,” Brown says. “I pick her out first and then I try and look up at the highest point I can see, pick out a white jersey and sing the anthem as proud as I can. You try not to get too emotional because that can have an effect on your performance.” And when the first high ball heads his way against Scotland on Saturday? Will he flinch inside? “I don’t think so. It hasn’t been an issue in training. The way I play I can’t afford to do that because it would take so much away from my game. I think I’m 100% committed every time I’m going for a ball. Hopefully, I will just switch into automatic mode and won’t think too much of it.” When it comes to mind over matter, there are few to match him. Find out more about concussion via the RFU’s new online education course www.englandrugby.com/headcase
